name: Royale-les-Eaux
description: Fictional French seaside resort town setting of 'Casino Royale'.

content.title: Overview
content.body: Royale-les-Eaux is a fictional coastal town on the northern coast of France, depicted as a luxurious and bustling resort known for its casinos and seaside attractions. It provides the atmospheric backdrop for much of Fleming’s 'Casino Royale.'

content.title: Appearance
content.body: The town features grand hotels, casinos such as the Casino Royale, promenades, and a vibrant social scene. Its architecture reflects a mixture of Belle Époque luxury and post-war recovery, evoking a sense of glamour and intrigue.

content.title: History
content.body: Though entirely fictional, Royale-les-Eaux closely resembles real French Riviera towns like Deauville or Trouville-sur-Mer, known for their gambling establishments and elite visitors. The town’s seedy undercurrent is emblematic of the espionage tensions permeating the narrative.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: It is the main locus of the novel’s action where Bond’s critical baccarat encounter unfolds. The resort's pampered exterior belies the dangerous power struggles occurring within its casinos and hotels.
